column2: The myths of the Dark Continent intrigue me.
The Inna's Apotheosis

The Inna, the mother of us all, for long has being reduced to the role of a mere subject or adviser of powerful rulers.
But those dark days are over today. All the great Magadjas have met today in the court of [From.GetTitledName] and have invoked the bori spirits to elevate [Root.RelHead.GetTitledName] to a divine character.

The Inna, possessed by the spirit of Magiro, the oldest and wisest of the bori, has received the authority to decide on all the spiritual issues that concern the faithful. The drums and marimbas rumble through the streets while the great mother is carried by her parishioners to the Kano temple, from where she will now rule the city until the end of time.
Glory to our mother, [Root.RelHead.GetBestName]!

To all my faithful,\nFor long the unbelievers have lived in our lands, shared our tables and enjoyed the protection of our spears. This is an example of the infinite tolerance of our faith. However it’s time for these fools who reject the truth of the Jan Gari to repay our generosity. For this reason I authorize the lords to tax their unfaithful peasantry.\nLovingly, your Inna
The Inna's word bring joy to my soul… and my pocket.

The Tan Garki are the children of the shield, the warrior spirits summoned by all of the great fighters of the central Sahel.
Recently a group of devout soldiers has organized a meeting in the old city of Kano, at the great ceremony presided over by the Inna herself, the soldiers were possessed by the boris of war and took an oath to defend the faith by any means necessary.

The group of warrior devotees calls themselves the "Living Tan Garki" and are willing to fight for any ruler who marches his armies in the name of the Inna.
The spirits themselves will now fight on our side!
Possessed warriors? A most curious thing.
These infidels are possessed by demons!

The tyeddo are a caste of West African warriors, sometimes considered to be slave warriors. Recently the many communities of the A Tat Roog faith have pooled their resources together to assemble a new tyeddo army that would not be loyal to any particular king, but to the faith itself.\n\nThese Sacred Tyeddo soldiers will dedicate their lives to protect any devout of Roog and will guide their swords not by the command of monarchs, but by the Yoonir star.
These faithful are slaves to Roog and no one else.
Noble slaves, but still slaves.
A slave army? Pitiful.

In 703 the great Queen Dihya, last of the faithful Amazigh monarchs, was stripped of her rightful title by the invading Arab usurpers. For generations the remnants of their army and its descendants have wandered the Sahara selling their sweat and blood as mercenaries, dishonoring their heritage like vulgar sellswords.\n\nHowever, today everything changed. The new commander of the band has made an oath to only fight in the name of the true faith, and only pledge his spear to those marching in the name of Tanit. Generations after the fall of Numidia, its orphans will fight only for the Amazigh faithful.
With their aid, North Africa shall be free once more.
An old and proud group, if ever there was one.
Just the remains of a defeated pagan army.

It seems that my interest in the the legends of the Sudan has come to the attention of one of their practitioners within the realm. We met and have had the most fruitful discussions about theology and other matters.
The African Holy Wars

In response to the endless aggression of the Abrahamic invaders, the Great [Root.GetTitledName] has made a call to all true believers of the Sudan to take arms in defense of the old gods. All reformed religious leaders in the southern continent have answered the call and will now be ready to launch Great Holy Wars. This seems to be the beginning of a new era of military conquest for the Sudanese gods’ most faithful.
They will come to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName] by reason or by force.
A new dawn comes to the faithful.
Horrors from the Dark Continent!
Find a Way, or Make One

In ancient times when Dido reigned in her city of gold and spices, when Hannibal and Hasdrubal commanded the armies of Numidia in European lands, when the Berber ruled the earth and the Phoenician the sea, there was a dream named Carthage. A dream that ended when the Italian eagle divided our people and plundered our lands, covering our hopes with salt.\n\nToday the Phoenicians are only a memory, but we children of Numidia are still here, and we still venerate the great goddess Tanit. And with great effort we have managed to restore her empire, to once again make ours all that the sea and the desert touch.
For us, there is no spring. Just the wind that smells fresh before the storm.
Reborn From the Ashes and Salt

Something that seemed impossible has happened.  In the lands of North Africa the Amazigh leader [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has made an important proclamation: the ancient Carthaginian Empire has been reborn from its ashes.\n\nThrough the streets of the old city of Carthage the marabouts dance singing chants in honor of the old Punic-Berber goddess Tanit, and all the pagans of North Africa make toasts in honor of the new emperor. Only time will tell if this new empire will achieve supremacy in the Mediterranean Sea or if it will perish like its predecessor.

One would believe that killing one hundred thousand men and salting their land would be enough for them to learn their lesson, but still, here we are. The pagan and grotesque [From.GetDynName], a worshiper of the demonic Punic goddess, has proclaimed the creation of a new Carthaginian Empire. This affront is certainly not something I can ignore as the head of the true Roman Empire.\n\nRome has defeated Carthage three times on the battlefield, and we are not afraid to do it a fourth time.
They know how to gain a victory, but do they know how to make use of it?
Carthago delenda est!

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], I have heard from a good source that now you pretend that your African dominions are a Carthaginian Empire reborn. If so, I can assure you that in my position as ruler of the true Roman Empire I will follow in the footsteps of the good Scipio and salt your lands once more.\nYour's truly\n[From.GetTitledName]

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], what was it that Cato the Elder used to say? Carthago delenda est? If you want to revive an empire that only deserves the grave then you will have to face the full force of the civilized world. If you want to save yourself some humiliation maybe you should salt your own land before I get the chance.\nBest wishes, [From.GetTitledName]

To the [GetFromRootInsult] [Root.GetDynName], when my messengers gave me the news, I almost died of laughter. It seems you have committed the foolishness of resurrecting an empire that should have been confined to the history books.
It does not matter, as Emperor of the Romans and successor of Aeneas I will take care of plowing your armies as Aeneas plowed your predecessor.
From Rome with love,
[From.GetTitledName]
Fourth time's the charm.
You will cry: Hannibal at the Gates!
Sulla potuit, ego non potero?

A wicked soul known as [From.GetDynName] has been proclaimed [From.GetTitledNameWithNick]. And just like that a new pretender to the corpse of our old enemy, Rome, has been brought into the world. We all know the tale of the noble queen Dido whose heart was broken by the lecherous Aeneas, making the queen proclaim eternal hate between the men of Rome and Carthage. Today it is me who sits on the throne of Dido, and for that reason alone the sacred oath made in the name of the goddess Tanit cannot be ignored.\n\nMany will say that [From.GetDynName] is no true Roman and that the new realm is in no way the Roman Empire. But I know in my heart of hearts that I will think of [From.GetHerHim] as Roman when I put my sword through [From.GetHerHis] heart.
We are destined to do this forever.

To the Roman pretender [Root.GetDynName], the news has reached my ears that you have taken the crown of the empire of the Romans. Many will say that you are not a true Roman, but I give you my word that I believe you a true Scipio Africanus. I'll have that in mind when I put your neck under my axe and cover your lands with salt.\nYour's truly,\n[From.GetTitledName]
Carthago delenda est!
You are currently the highest magistrate of the reborn Carthaginian Empire. May your reign be a prosperous one!
Omek tannou!
You are no longer the ruler of the Carthaginian Empire. It will surely crumble without your guiding hand to lead it.
You are no longer the ruler of the Carthaginian Empire. It turns out you know how to gain a victory, but you do not know how to make use of it.
Carthage is lost without me!
Furthermore, Carthage has been destroyed.
Rome Burns!

In an act of bloody revenge for the destruction of Carthage centuries ago, [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] has ordered the destruction of the eternal city. The Amazigh soldiers loot everything they can carry while they lock the local priests in their temples and set them on fire.\n\n[Root.GetTitledFirstName] [Root.GetHerselfHimself] now parades through the burning Rome, in a chariot pulled by two elephants, throwing salt into the streets, in mockery of what in ancient times was the ceremony of the Roman Triumph. This abominable act will certainly not only damage the reputation of the city, as its perpetrator claims, but of the Catholic faith.
A toast to old Hannibal!

In an act of bloody revenge for the destruction of Carthage centuries ago, [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has ordered the destruction of the eternal city. The Amazigh soldiers loot everything they can carry while they lock the local priests in their temples and set them on fire.\n\n[From.GetTitledFirstName] [From.GetHerselfHimself] now parades through the burning Rome, in a chariot pulled by two elephants, throwing salt into the streets, in mockery of what in ancient times was the ceremony of the Roman Triumph. This abominable act will certainly not only damage the reputation of the city, as its perpetrator claims, but of the Catholic faith.
When Rome falls, the world shall fall!
The Fall of the Second Rome

Centuries ago the first Rome enslaved the innocent of the first Carthage and salted the land, but today the second Carthage is taking its revenge on the second Rome. [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] has unleashed a furious army into what was once called the city of the world's desire.\n\nThe Nova Roma of Constantinus and his “carpenter god”, as the invading Amazigh call it, is now covered in the blood of those who resisted the attacking soldiers. All the local priests were taken to the Hagia Sophia and, according to those who witnessed the horror, sacrificed in the name of some North African goddess. This day will be marked forever in the history books as the great Carthaginian revenge.
See the glyph of Tanit, in this sign we will conquer!

Centuries ago the first Rome enslaved the innocent of the first Carthage and salted the land, but today the second Carthage is taking its revenge on the second Rome. [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] has unleashed a furious army into what was once called the city of the world's desire.\n\nThe Nova Roma of Constantinus and his “carpenter god”, as the invading Amazigh call it, is now covered in the blood of those who resisted the attacking soldiers. All the local priests were taken to the Hagia Sophia and, according to those who witnessed the horror, sacrificed in the name of some North African goddess. This day will be marked forever in the history books as the great Carthaginian revenge.
Is the ghost of Odoacer haunting the world?
Once More, With Feeling

The old Carthage was built, destroyed and rebuilt. It seems that its African gods have doomed it to repeat this process forever. The armies of [Root.GetDynName], who goes by the title of [Root.GetTitledNameWithNick] and claims to be the successor of the old Rome, are now reenacting what Scipio did so many centuries ago when he burned the city to the ground and salted the land.\n\nThe self-proclaimed Roman soldiers now march through streets of the Carthaginian capital, using the sword on those who resist and the chain on those who don’t. The African temples have being defaced, the idols smashed and the marabouts are now corpses or slaves. Somewhere, in this world or the next, the ghost of Hannibal cries bitter tears for a second time, as Scipio mocks him.
Roma invicta est!

The old Carthage was built, destroyed and rebuilt. It seems that its African gods have doomed it to repeat this process forever. The armies of [From.GetDynName], who goes by the title of [From.GetTitledNameWithNick] and claims to be the successor of the old Rome, are now reenacting what Scipio did so many centuries ago when he burned the city to the ground and salted the land.\n\nThe self-proclaimed Roman soldiers now march through streets of the Carthaginian capital, using the sword on those who resist and the chain on those who don’t. The African temples have being defaced, the idols smashed and the marabouts are now corpses or slaves. Somewhere, in this world or the next, the ghost of Hannibal cries bitter tears for a second time, as Scipio mocks him.
Our only crime was daring to dream with a second chance.
These Carthaginians, when will they learn?
The Old Borders are Restored

The gods have given to man no sharper spur to victory than contempt of death. The old empire, which was once stabbed in the heart and left for dead in ashes and salt, has now been restored to its full glory. Never again shall the sons of Carthage fear the crushing defeat, never again shall the mothers of Carthage see their sons taken in chains by Northerner tyrants.\n\nThe priests of Tanit celebrate across the Maghreb, for once again they are protected by the one true heir of the beloved Dido.  Merchants set sails for places yet unexplored as once Hanno did.   Gold and prosperity once again fill the metropolises of Africa. What was built with Phoenician ingenuity and Numidian blood has been rebuild by their only heirs and a forgotten nation has now a second chance in this world.
A day that will forever be remembered.

In an effort to convince the court of my piety, I have chosen to attend [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyName] and give a grand speech to my people, and to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName]. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] eyes me curiously as I enter the building, and I stop for moment to gather my thoughts. May [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] forgive me, but I need to impress these people and choose my words carefully.
a possession ceremony
the local temple

As I step up to the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyLocation], people eye me carefully. They depend upon me, as [Root.GetTitle] and my connection to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName], to guide them. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] nods encouragingly at me, and I look around to study the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyHangings]. When I finally speak, I imagine that I am praising [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] – unsurprising, my words have never seemed more true.
center of the room
altar
musicians of the possession ceremony
ornamental masks hanging from the walls
Tanit glyphs carved into the walls of the temple

As I step up to the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyLocation], people eye me warily. They depend upon me, as [Root.GetTitle] and my connection to [Root.Religion.GetHighGodName], to guide them. The [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] nods solemnly at me. I look look around to study the [Root.GetReligiousCeremonyHangings], silently begging [Root.TrueReligion.GetHighGodName] for some surge of inspiration – it never comes and my heart sinks. I leave the center of the ceremony leavy everybody confused.

I walk to the center of the ceremony and make a quick decision – as I reach my place, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin singing [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I sing, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, everyone seems to be holding their breath. For a moment I worry that my stunt has failed. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] exclaims "A VISION! My [Root.GetLordLady], let me help you stand!"

I step up to the altar and make a quick decision – as I reach the center of the stage, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin quoting [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I speak, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, everyone seems to be holding their breath. For a moment I worry that my stunt has failed. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] exclaims "A VISION! My [Root.GetLordLady], let me help you stand!"

I walk to the center of the ceremony and make a quick decision – as I reach a group of people, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin singing [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I sing, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, they start to whisper. For a moment I am convinced that my stunt has succeeded. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] prods at me. "Uhm, my [Root.GetLordLady]? Let's get you back onto your feet."

I step forwards and make a bold decision – as I reach a group of people, I collapse to the floor. The worshipers gasp as I, their [Root.GetTitle], begin quoting fragments of [Root.Religion.GetScriptureName]. I roll my eyes back as I speak, as if confronting the skies themselves. When my last words ring out, they start to whisper. For a moment I am convinced that my stunt has succeeded. Then the [Root.Religion.GetPriestTitle] prods at me. "Uhm, my [Root.GetLordLady]? Let's get you back onto your feet."

In the ethereal realm of Jan Gari, the Bori spirits exist in a transcendental state incomprehensible to the mortals. If I make special contact with one of the great bori clans and enter into communion with their king, it is possible that the spirits will grant me their blessing.
Time to chose.
Maybe another time.

While I make an effort so that my soul comes in contact with the Jan Gari plane, I face the decision of which spirit I should ask for favor. There are six major categories of spirits each with their own hierarchy and a powerful spiritual king who rules over them. Which of these spiritual courts will I pay homage to?
I consider Yan Riga, the city spirits.
I consider Babbaku, the rural spirits.
I consider Tan Garki, the warrior spirits.
I had something else in mind.
I consider Samari, the young feminine spirits.
I consider Yayan Zanzanna, the children of the plague.
I consider Tan Dowa, the wild spirits.
Maybe another court has what I require.

The Yan Riga, that is, those who wear clothes, are the most civilized spirits. It is said that they live in cities and know about the wisdom of men who can read. Above them reigns the spiritual king Mallam Alhaji, the so-called father of many and the oldest of all spirits.
Begin the song of The Learned One!
Yan Riga are not for me.

The Babbaku, that is, the black ones, are inhabitants of rural villages. Some are farmers and other hunters, but all of them enjoy the country life and know how to make use of the land. Above them reigns Mai-Ja-Ciki, the one who crawls on the floor on his stomach, who is like a snake and can not speak in human language.
Oh, Wizard of the Night, what do you say?
Babbaku are not for me.

The Tan Garki, that is, the sons of the shield, are the great warriors among the spirits. Many brave fighters seek their protection, but the true custodians of their blessings are the generals and strategists. The head of this spiritual army is Garki Baba, the great shield, protector of those who march to the battlefield.
You followers of the chief, show me the horsemen!
Tan Garki are not for me.

Samari, the spirits of youth but also of femininity. Interestingly they are led by Ba-Gudu, the one who does not run, who is neither female nor young. It is a court full of curious talents such as giving good or bad luck to gamblers, persuading a man to desire his brother's wife, or making the breasts of young girls irritate by awakening her desires.
Let him who has two wives give one!
Samari are not for me.

The Yayan Zanzanna, the children of the plague, are child spirits with dominion over any disease, spreading smallpox and other evils among mortals. They are led by Nana Mariyamu, the naughty little queen who likes to give headaches and irritated eyes to those who are mean to her. The whole court is playful and likes to clap for no reason, after all they are just children.
Beautiful is she with her small spots!
Yayan Zanzanna are not for me.

The Tan Dowa are spirits of the jungle, they do not resemble any human but are nature in its purest state. They are spirits of the lion, the hyena and the elephant, but also the guard dog that protects man. Zaki the lion is the first among them, and more than king of the court it can be said that he is simply the strongest among a group of beasts without a leader.
The Lion is to be feared!
Tan Dowa are not for me.

There are hundreds of gods worshiped among the Amazigh, many taken from the cult of Egypt, the mythology of the Greeks or our own traditions as Berber peoples. Making a small offering could earn me the favor of one of these great gods.
Time to chose.
Maybe another time.
I raise a prayer to the heavens and the earth under my feet, I imagine the holy lands of the Maghreb in all its extension and I feel a great peace. But to what god am I raising my prayers?
Tanit, the great mother.
Änti, the mighty giant.
Gurzil, the bull of war.
I had something else in mind.
Magec, lady of the sun.
Set, lord of chaos.
Maybe another deity has what I require.

Tanit is the mother goddess who brings the rains to the arid lands and gives fertility to women without children. Tanit was first worshiped among both Numidians and Phoenicians, eventually becoming the patroness of Carthage. From there, her cult spread to all the Mediterranean.
Her blessing will bring happiness and love to my family.
Tanit is not for me.

Änti was a powerful giant, born of the very earth, who became the most formidable fighter in the whole world because while he was in contact with his mother he became invincible. The Greek men tell that the giant was defeated by Heracles, but we the Amazigh know that this story is nothing but foolishness. Änti simply returned to his mother's womb, in the Tangier, where he patiently awaits a new challenger.
With the blessing of Änti I will also be invincible.
Änti is not for me.

Gurzil is the great god-bull of war. Many have been the warriors who have sought his blessing on the battlefield. Ierna dedicated his life to the faith so that the bull would protect him against the Greek emperor, and Dihya bore his image when she confronted the Islamic invaders.
I raise a prayer to the great bull, guide my armies in war and bring death to my enemies.
Gurzil is not for me.

The sun lady Magec is beautiful like no other and full of blessings even to those who do not revere her. In the old traditions the lady of the sun was kidnapped by the nefarious Guayota, who held her inside a volcano in the Guanche Islands, where men speak in whistles.
The sun that illuminates all land will let me understand it better.
Magec is not for me.

Set is a god of chaos, the desert, the wild storms and of violence among men. In the ancient times when the pharaohs still ruled their river kingdom, they also though he was the god of foreigners, because he loved us Amazighs. Set is a trickster but also a protector who fights a constant battle against death itself.
Give me some of your cleverness lord of chaos.
Set is not for me.
